title: 115_hr5056
content: The Act is titled the "Confederate Commemorative Works Inventory and Joint Resource Study Act". It includes findings related to the Act. The American Civil War was fought between 1861 and 1865. Efforts to preserve pivotal battle locations began as early as 1864. The National Park Service preserves natural and cultural resources, including sites dedicated to the Civil War. The Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense administer Confederate commemorative works on public lands. There are 147 national cemeteries in the United States, with fourteen maintained by the Department of the Interior. The Department of Defense administers 2 cemeteries and has jurisdiction over 10 major military installations named after Confederate leaders and Navy ships named after Confederate victories. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "Confederate commemorative work" as any work honoring Confederate individuals or units, including flags, symbols, monuments, statues, or plaques. The term "Confederate flag" refers to the national flag of the Confederacy from 1861 to 1865, including various designs. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Park Service, and "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Defense, and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in relation to Federal land under their jurisdiction. SEC. 4. INVENTORY AND RESOURCE STUDY. Each Secretary must conduct an inventory of Confederate commemorative works and submit it to the Director. The Director will then conduct a special resource study on Civil War-related works from 1861 to 1865, evaluating their historical significance and suitability. The Director will conduct a special resource study on Confederate commemorative works, evaluating their historical significance, feasibility, and potential for national recognition. The report must be completed within 2 years of funding availability. The Secretary of the Interior will submit a report to the House and Senate committees containing the findings and recommendations of the special resource study on Confederate commemorative works within 2 years of funding availability.
